Abandoned

No response from submitter.
nit: const& std::string& instead? just for consistency.

oops I meant
```
const std::string&
```
Done
use contains() like how you did with unordered_set?
Done. Nice, C++20.
const reference instead?
Done

can't we declare this outside of the  for loops and then at the end.

```
memoryAsyncResp->asyncResponse->res.jsonValue["Members@odata.count"] = members.size();
```
?
We can.

does std::bind_front not work here?

I know it doesn't work in some cases.
No. async_method_call can't take bind_front today.

If we are going to make a copy here since the dimmServices will go out of scope, can't we just copy dimmServices in the first place?

Same with partitionServices

----

Wait, this function is not async so the data in dimmServices won't go out os scope. How come we need to copy here?
I guess I somehow messed it up during rebase. This is not needed.

This needs more explaination.  The pattern here appears to be an old pattern that we used a long time ago (still used in sensors) but a pattern that we stopped using because it was very difficult to get correct, and relies on destructor behavior, which can cause issues on shutdown if a request is in flight when we receive SIGTERM.

A little more details here would be good.

The pattern here refers to using GetManagedObjects to handle `$expand=*($levels=1)`, rather than sending a bunch of GetAllProperties which is slow.

I will add that into the commit message.
Done
What system did you test with that had a non ECC RDIMM.....   Was this tested on a real system?  It's possible there's another bug somewhere.

This data is from my mock systems. Does service validator validates $expand result today? 

I compared the $expand=. JSON before and after this change, there is no difference. 

I also ran service validator on real system.

As you can see in your test results, the order is incorrect here.  In the non-efficient handler, dimm0 would've come before dimm1.  Using the generic functions (getCollectionMembers) doesn't have this bug.  I suspect that you need to adapt your code to still use getCollectionMembers, but then call your efficient expand handlers when complete.
Wait, is this a bug? Is there requirement on the order of the Members?
FWIW, I can sort the json. That's what the sensor codes are doing IIRC.

> Wait, is this a bug? Is there requirement on the order of the Members?

Expand should return the same values as if it had been constructed from independent pieces, this includes the order of the collection.

You've avoided the problem of the reason this bug was caused is because it didn't reuse any of the existing code for the handler, and opted to do a completely different codepath.

> it didn't reuse any of the existing code for the handler

This is more or less a completely new optimization. Not much codes can be shared.

> Expand should return the same values as if it had been constructed from independent pieces, this includes the order of the collection.

This makes sense. I didn't see it explicitly documented anywhere in Redfish spec. Though there are words like "Returns a hyperlink and its contents in-line with retrieved resources, as if a GET call response was included in-line with that hyperlink."

It can be fixed via a sort. https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/002d39b4a7a5ed7166e2acad84e0943c3def9492/redfish-core/include/utils/collection.hpp#L61.

In the sensor case, I believe what we did is we shared all the code up to the point where we would start doing per-sensor things, then we kept a list of either one sensor we were creating, or all the sensors, and we would only populate the thing being selected.  IN that way, we kept the code the same, even if it did slow down the single sensor case a little (in practice it wasn't much).

Maybe we could do something similar here?

> Maybe we could do something similar here?

Yes, we can use this code path to fetch a single DIMM. But it will be slower than call GetAllProperties for a single sensor. Ideally this doesn't matter since it's still fast enough and in most cases we will use expand.

What do you think? If you agree with sharing the codes for querying a single DIMM, I can do the change. It will get a bunch of codes deleted.

> > Maybe we could do something similar here?
> 
> Yes, we can use this code path to fetch a single DIMM. But it will be slower than call GetAllProperties for a single sensor.
> Ideally this doesn't matter 

Yep, this is what we found in the sensor stuff.  The per-dbus-call overhead outweighed the size of the requests being sent and received.

> since it's still fast enough and in most cases we will use expand.
> 
> What do you think? If you agree with sharing the codes for querying a single DIMM, I can do the change. It will get a bunch of codes deleted.

Yes, I think that's the right approach here.

Done. Only one codepath now.

PTAL. I also updated the testing result in commit message.
I didn't make it all the way through this patchset yet.

As a pattern, having a per-schema defined AsyncResponse object is generally not a pattern we want to promote.  We still use it in the sensors case because nobody has ported it back, but I'm not sure we want it here.  Generally the pattern is to capture AsyncResp, and append objects to the response object as required.

What we want is that after finishing DIMM async calls, we do several other async calls to modify the DIMM object and append some data (health, DIMM partitions).

Why is per-schema defined AsyncResponse object bad? It's not necessarily needed to be named as |XyzAsyncResponse|. It just needs to hold the original AsyncResponse and append data to its json.
FWIW, I changed the class name. And yes, its main functionality is to "capture the AsyncResponse shared pointer and append objects to the response object as required".

> Why is per-schema defined AsyncResponse object bad?

Because they caused lots of code duplication and bugs because of the complex code they generated.  They also impose a form of "caching" that requires significant amounts of memory, and leads to patterns where people store large amounts of data in the Async object, just to release it all at the end, which can lead to OOM conditions when under load.  It probably doesn't make sense to go back 4 years in the git logs to figure out exactly why (it might not be well documented there either).
nit, typo.
Done
common error 13

It doesn't look like https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/COMMON_ERRORS.md#13-complete-replacement-of-the-response-object.

If you refer to not populating ID when an error happens, done.
Ack
it's still brace initialization;  You're right, I should document that better.  COMMON_ERRORS isn't great documentation for that.  Regardless, please use the style we use elsewhere.
please use urlFromPieces for constructing this url
Done
Please don't duplicate this call (you duplicate it 3 times in this function).  Also, this function can fail, in which case you need to handle the error.
Done
nit, typo.
Done

Is there a reason none of the old code could be used in this case?  We're adding 300 lines of new things just for this case, and duplicating a lot of the dbus -> json code, which has caused some bugs.

The reason why we can reuse codes in SensorCollection is that Thermal and Power are AutoExpand.

MemoryCollection is not like this. Current codes only support sending GetAllProperties DBus call per DIMM. This commits add codes to use GetManagedObjects to fetch all DIMMs of the service. I have tried my best to reuse a lot of existing codes (e.g., assemble properties from dbus response). That's why I sent https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/53822, https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/53823/8, and https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/53944/2

I also explained the main idea (use GetManagedObjects to improve performance) in the commit message.

Please reopen if you have better ideas.

If in the future more and more resources need this efficient handler. I can think of creating a general helper class (similar to today's getResourceCollection). But that's not what I want to do in this iteration.
nit, typo.
Done
PTAL
nit: how were these numbers chosen? Could it be useful to add a comment on what they represent?

these are http return codes

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status
Oh I'm a dummy - you can see I haven't reviewed much bmcweb patches before 😢
So how would one implement this on Processor.h for example? I guess we would have to implement what you've done here, but fit it into Processor?
Yes, I will also look into making part of the codes reusable for threads
ACK
bump
bump. PTAL.

Overall, I'm struggling this a little because of its complexity.  We allowed the complexity into the Sensor subsystem because it improved the performance by 100X for something that we expect to be polled quite often, and to date, it has caused significant maintenance problems when new things are added, but in that case, it was probably worth it, as it dropped a 1 minute poll loop down to a couple seconds.

Arguably this is a different case, because we're talking about inventory items here, and anything we do is going to need to be copied to drives, storage, network interfaces, ect.  Given that as the future, I'm a little worried about how little code is shared, given that it can lead to subtle bugs that are hard to catch (like the array ordering thing that I caught below.)

Given 2 second response time is well within what we allow, I wonder if 300 lines of complex code is worth the difference here, or if there's some improvements we can make to reuse more code between the expand case and the non.  Nan, is this something you've thought about?
Also, given the code duplication, this adds about 7KB (about 1%) to the compressed binary size of bmcweb.  That seems pretty high for just one handler, although I'm not really sure what's causing it.

> Arguably this is a different case, because we're talking about inventory items here, and anything we do is going to need to be copied to drives, storage, network interfaces, ect.  

The improvement depends on the number of inventory items. For CPU, I would imagine it doesn't matter too much. For DIMMs can vary and increase in the future. For threads, I would imagine it will be another big improvement.

> Given that as the future, I'm a little worried about how little code is shared, given that it can lead to subtle bugs that are hard to catch (like the array ordering thing that I caught below.)
> or if there's some improvements we can make to reuse more code between the expand case and the non.

I have thought about this. My initial idea is to submit this as the first iteration. In the thread collection which we mostly like **have to** implement an efficient expand soon (there will be hundreds of threads), we then think about how these codes can be shared. We can also help clean up sensors.

From what I can imagine, yes, many of the codes can be shared (e.g., search services, search ObjectManagers, call GetManagedObjects). The public interface will be something that takes functors to assemble JSON response from ManagedObjects dbus responses.

What's your opinion? What I don't want to do is spend time working on a generic solution before the backend is even ready. Do we accept review this patch in details, resolve bugs if any, and then when developing backend for threads, share this code.
Ack. This is aligned in another thread.
I didn't mean to resolve this.  This needs addressed.
typo.
Done
DO we do this check in the other health checks?  I didn't think so?
That's a good point. Let me just remove.
nit: just std::string here when we can specify it. (just something that bmcweb preferred)

Thanks. Let me ask maintainers to double check.

Ed, Gunner, what's the convention?

To me, MapperGetSubTreeResponse is a well-known type and these types in the loop are also very clear. Using explicit type in this nested loop might introduce indent and hurt readability.

> Ed, Gunner, what's the convention?

don't use auto unless it aids in the readability.  Where you use it on line 1084 aids in readability, because it reduces a significant amount of time reading the type (std::pair<.... ect>)

In this case, it doesn't help in readability:

for (const std::string&

is easier/faster to read than

for (const auto&.
I was actually pretty curious about best practice about auto - this seems in line with what I had in mind as well.

From the Google coding standard, (which is what I follow here in leiu of cpp core guidelines having any guidance)

"The fundamental rule is: use type deduction only to make the code clearer or safer, and do not use it merely to avoid the inconvenience of writing an explicit type. When judging whether the code is clearer, keep in mind that your readers are not necessarily on your team, or familiar with your project, so types that you and your reviewer experience as unnecessary clutter will very often provide useful information to others. For example, you can assume that the return type of make_unique<Foo>() is obvious, but the return type of MyWidgetFactory() probably isn't."
Done
?  Why do we need a memory namespace, and if we do, why do we declare it so late?
I was trying to hide these codes. I can change it to details if you want.
yes, a details namespace or an anonymous namespace would be better. here.
Generally in this case we would sort on insert into the array
Apologize, you suggest using a sorted container like set? What's the difference compared to sorting at the end?

Do you want me to abandon https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/55047/4?

I can do this insertion sort.

Lets figure out if we can even use ObjectManager in this case before you spend a bunch more time on this.  I suspect we can't.

We could use ObjectManager in sensor because there were only 2 sensor producing daemons (only 1 at the time we did it).  There are lots of inventory producing daemons, and the dbus interface spec for Memory doesn't require object manager, so this would be a breaking change (I think.  Lets get the data and figure out a plan.)

>  There are lots of inventory producing daemon

What are those inventory daemon? Are they all upstream? If so, we can probably add ObjectManager. I thought adding ObjectManager is aligned with the dbus convention.

> >  There are lots of inventory producing daemon
> 
> What are those inventory daemon?

I don't know the complete list of the top of my head.  I would probably go system by system, as there are a lot of them.


> Are they all upstream? If so, we can probably add ObjectManager.

Something to be discussed with the relevant maintainers.  Lets start by getting a discussion going in phosphor-dbus-interfaces about why this is required.

> I thought adding ObjectManager is aligned with the dbus convention.

ObjectManager is optional, and not required, so I'm not sure what you mean by "aligned".  We modified the Sensor interface to require it, but most of the other interfaces don't, so it's pretty likely there are a lot of implementations that either don't have it, or put it in the wrong path.
I realized that insertion doesn't work unless we make significant code changes. Currently we need ptr of DIMMs to be stable.

Considering that this has impact against real hardware backends (as pointed out by the ManagedObjects thing), please test against a real system.

"mock system" isn't a good enough definition.

Apologize, I have tested on real hardware. It's already in the commit message. Please review the entire commit message.

This testing result on "mock system" is good since it doesn't have any potential secret messages like serial numbers.

Let me know if this doesn't make sense.

I should've realized this earlier, but have you verified all the various inventory systems implement ObjectManager?  I don't think they all do.  There's only 2 producers of sensors, which is why it can rely on ObjectManager.  There's lots of producers of Memory.

As another meta comment, I'd like to see us stabilize, secure, and get the existing expand stuff enabled by default ahead of trying to optimize it.  There are likely a number of things that we're missing that will be figured out when it gets turned on within the project, so I'd like to avoid over optimizing where possible.

Considering that in upstream, no real platform can use this code, that is limiting the amount of test results we can get for this patchset.

Could you explain why "expand" is not stable or secure besides that we don't limit the expand level size?

> Considering that in upstream, no real platform can use this code, that is limiting the amount of test results we can get for this patchset.

Why? This commit changes the code path of individual DIMM as you suggested in previous comment. Most of the code will be used by others
I have verified `smbios-mdr`. What are the other producers? Adding ObjectManager is very trivial, right?

Lets move the discussion to discord.

> Why?

No systems enable the expand option, so there's no way to run this on a real system in a release firmware.  Yes, I appreciate that you've tested on one system, but given that we've had issues with ObjectManager support in the past (We still have lots of problems with sensors even today), we need more testing than just one system.

I don't know them all off the top of my head.  We'd have to go digging through the code.

This has been a problem for the sensor code you copied this pattern from already, which is why I'm hesitant to add it here.
Dig into what codes? Are they all in upstream?

Any dbus daemon that publishes an inventory that might include memory.  No, not all of them are upstream, and while we should do our best to not unnecessarily break peoples downstream (we don't like it when others do it to us) we can just publish the new interface requirements to phosphor-dbus-interfaces, and the downstream ones will need to adapt.
I agree with Ed here, I think we need a requirement added to phosphor-dbus-interfaces. I also think we need to look at all upstream dbus daemon that publishes an inventory

Just for anyone watching, we should not be explicitly looking up the ObjectManager.  It needs defined at an interface level that:
1. The inventory interfaces require an ObjectManager
2. What path that object manager is at.

Granted we do this pattern in the sensor collection because that was moving from code that didn't follow the PDI standard, to code that could at least operate correctly when someone followed the standard, so we accepted some amount of tech debt there, because the existing tree was already "wrong".  I'm not willing to do it in this case where:
1. The existing code works to the standard.
2. This code is overly complex to support things that don't follow the standard.
3. Unlike sensors, it's not documented anywhere that an ObjectManager is required (although I think we all agree it should be).
4. The inventory system is used to generate 8-10 different APIs, where this pattern would need to be propagated (sensors generates 3 APIs, all that share identical code), thus significantly increasing the complexity of something already complex.

Next steps on getting this merged are in review in PDI.  This section of this patchset needs amended to assume a mapper path of /xyz/openbmc_project/inventory, which can be done at any time.

After that, we need to propagate the change to the various things in the system that put the ObjectManager at the root.

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/53824 was merged.

> Next steps on getting this merged are in review in PDI.  This section of this patchset needs amended to assume a mapper path of /xyz/openbmc_project/inventory, which can be done at any time.
> 
> After that, we need to propagate the change to the various things in the system that put the ObjectManager at the root.

Does this mean this is no blockers for the change now as long as we use the fixed ObjectManager path?
